speaker: BIRON
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: SCENE I. The same.

speaker: BIRON
text_entry: Enter the PRINCESS, and her train, a Forester, BOYET, ROSALINE, MARIA, and KATHARINE

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Was that the king, that spurred his horse so hard

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Against the steep uprising of the hill?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I know not; but I think it was not he.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Whoe'er a' was, a' show'd a mounting mind.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Well, lords, to-day we shall have our dispatch:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: On Saturday we will return to France.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: That we must stand and play the murderer in?

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Hereby, upon the edge of yonder coppice;

speaker: Forester
text_entry: A stand where you may make the fairest shoot.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: I thank my beauty, I am fair that shoot,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: And thereupon thou speak'st the fairest shoot.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: What, what? first praise me and again say no?

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: O short-lived pride! Not fair? alack for woe!

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Yes, madam, fair.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Nay, never paint me now:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Here, good my glass, take this for telling true:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Fair payment for foul words is more than due.

speaker: Forester
text_entry: Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: See see, my beauty will be saved by merit!

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: O heresy in fair, fit for these days!

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: A giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: But come, the bow: now mercy goes to kill,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: And shooting well is then accounted ill.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Thus will I save my credit in the shoot:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Not wounding, pity would not let me do't;

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: If wounding, then it was to show my skill,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: That more for praise than purpose meant to kill.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: And out of question so it is sometimes,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Glory grows guilty of detested crimes,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: When, for fame's sake, for praise, an outward part,

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: We bend to that the working of the heart;

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: As I for praise alone now seek to spill

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: The poor deer's blood, that my heart means no ill.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Do not curst wives hold that self-sovereignty

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Only for praise sake, when they strive to be

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Lords o'er their lords?

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Only for praise: and praise we may afford

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: To any lady that subdues a lord.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Here comes a member of the commonwealth.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Enter COSTARD

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: God dig-you-den all! Pray you, which is the head lady?

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Thou shalt know her, fellow, by the rest that have no heads.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Which is the greatest lady, the highest?

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: The thickest and the tallest.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: The thickest and the tallest! it is so; truth is truth.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: An your waist, mistress, were as slender as my wit,

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: One o' these maids' girdles for your waist should be fit.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Are not you the chief woman? you are the thickest here.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: What's your will, sir? what's your will?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I have a letter from Monsieur Biron to one Lady Rosaline.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: O, thy letter, thy letter! he's a good friend of mine:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Stand aside, good bearer. Boyet, you can carve;

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Break up this capon.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I am bound to serve.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: This letter is mistook, it importeth none here;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: It is writ to Jaquenetta.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: We will read it, I swear.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Break the neck of the wax, and every one give ear.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Reads

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: 'By heaven, that thou art fair, is most infallible;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: true, that thou art beauteous; truth itself, that

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: thou art lovely. More fairer than fair, beautiful

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: than beauteous, truer than truth itself, have

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: commiseration on thy heroical vassal! The

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: magnanimous and most illustrate king Cophetua set

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: eye upon the pernicious and indubitate beggar

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Zenelophon; and he it was that might rightly say,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Veni, vidi, vici; which to annothanize in the

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: vulgar,--O base and obscure vulgar!--videlicet, He

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: came, saw, and overcame: he came, one; saw two;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: overcame, three. Who came? the king: why did he

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: come? to see: why did he see? to overcome: to

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: whom came he? to the beggar: what saw he? the

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: beggar: who overcame he? the beggar. The

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: conclusion is victory: on whose side? the king's.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: The captive is enriched: on whose side? the

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: beggar's. The catastrophe is a nuptial: on whose

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: side? the king's: no, on both in one, or one in

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: both. I am the king; for so stands the comparison:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: thou the beggar; for so witnesseth thy lowliness.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Shall I command thy love? I may: shall I enforce

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: thy love? I could: shall I entreat thy love? I

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: will. What shalt thou exchange for rags? robes;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: for tittles? titles; for thyself? me. Thus,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: expecting thy reply, I profane my lips on thy foot,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: my eyes on thy picture. and my heart on thy every

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: part. Thine, in the dearest design of industry,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: DON ADRIANO DE ARMADO.'

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: 'Gainst thee, thou lamb, that standest as his prey.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Submissive fall his princely feet before,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: And he from forage will incline to play:

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: But if thou strive, poor soul, what art thou then?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Food for his rage, repasture for his den.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: What plume of feathers is he that indited this letter?

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: What vane? what weathercock? did you ever hear better?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I am much deceived but I remember the style.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Else your memory is bad, going o'er it erewhile.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: This Armado is a Spaniard, that keeps here in court;

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: A phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes sport

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: To the prince and his bookmates.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Thou fellow, a word:

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Who gave thee this letter?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: I told you; my lord.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: To whom shouldst thou give it?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: From my lord to my lady.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: From which lord to which lady?

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: From my lord Biron, a good master of mine,

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: To a lady of France that he call'd Rosaline.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come, lords, away.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: To ROSALINE

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Here, sweet, put up this: 'twill be thine another day.

speaker: PRINCESS
text_entry: Exeunt PRINCESS and train

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Who is the suitor? who is the suitor?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Shall I teach you to know?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Ay, my continent of beauty.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Why, she that bears the bow.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Finely put off!

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: My lady goes to kill horns; but, if thou marry,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Hang me by the neck, if horns that year miscarry.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Finely put on!

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Well, then, I am the shooter.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: And who is your deer?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: If we choose by the horns, yourself come not near.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Finely put on, indeed!

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: You still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she strikes

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: at the brow.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: But she herself is hit lower: have I hit her now?

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Shall I come upon thee with an old saying, that was

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: a man when King Pepin of France was a little boy, as

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: touching the hit it?

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: So I may answer thee with one as old, that was a

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: woman when Queen Guinover of Britain was a little

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: wench, as touching the hit it.

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it,

speaker: ROSALINE
text_entry: Thou canst not hit it, my good man.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: An I cannot, cannot, cannot,

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: An I cannot, another can.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Exeunt ROSALINE and KATHARINE

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: By my troth, most pleasant: how both did fit it!

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: A mark marvellous well shot, for they both did hit it.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: A mark! O, mark but that mark! A mark, says my lady!

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Let the mark have a prick in't, to mete at, if it may be.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Wide o' the bow hand! i' faith, your hand is out.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Indeed, a' must shoot nearer, or he'll ne'er hit the clout.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: An if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the pin.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Come, come, you talk greasily; your lips grow foul.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: She's too hard for you at pricks, sir: challenge her to bowl.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: I fear too much rubbing. Good night, my good owl.

speaker: BOYET
text_entry: Exeunt BOYET and MARIA

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: By my soul, a swain! a most simple clown!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Lord, Lord, how the ladies and I have put him down!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: O' my troth, most sweet jests! most incony

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: vulgar wit!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely, as it

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: were, so fit.

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Armado o' th' one side,--O, a most dainty man!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: To see him walk before a lady and to bear her fan!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: To see him kiss his hand! and how most sweetly a'

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: will swear!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: And his page o' t' other side, that handful of wit!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Ah, heavens, it is a most pathetical nit!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Sola, sola!

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Shout within

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: Exit COSTARD, running

speaker: COSTARD
text_entry: LOVE'S LABOURS LOST
